question:
A meme has a reproductive number of R0 = 4, i.e. the mean excess degree of the effective network across which it is spreading is q = 4. Let's say the mean degree of this network is z = 3 and there are no degree correlations. You want to stop the meme by vaccinating people, using a vaccine that gives sterilizing immunity, so that a vaccinated person cannot transmit the meme. What proportion of the nodes do you need to vaccinate if you vaccinate random people? Also what proportion of nodes would you need to vaccinate if you are just vaccinating people who have a degree of exactly k = 10.address this question in both scenarios in analytcal and simulation approaches.
 This question need to be addressed analytically and then simulated to see if the analytical solutions are also valid by simualtion comprehensively.
 please do not ask the user any question, use other tools to address the question

We have completed Discovery, Modeling, Simulation and a first-pass quantitative analysis.  Key analytic results: (i) random vaccination threshold v_c = 75 %; (ii) vaccinating all k = 10 nodes (12.5 % of population in this degree-heterogeneous network) is sufficient to push the effective reproduction number below unity.  We generated a 10 000-node configuration-model graph (degree 10 with probability 0.125, degree 2 otherwise), verified that  ⟨k⟩≈3 and q≈4.33, calibrated β so that R0 = 4, and ran three FastGEMF SIR simulations (no vaccination, 75 % random vaccination, 12.4 % targeted high-degree vaccination).  Results files are stored in output/results-10.csv, …png, etc.  Metrics confirm analytics: with 75 % random vaccination the epidemic barely grows (peak I ≈0.25 %), and with targeted high-degree vaccination the epidemic is small and short-lived (peak I ≈0.9 %, dies out by t≈6).  In the next step I will:
1.  Re-format the quantitative analysis into a clear Results/Discussion narrative with numeric tables and figures; 2.  Write the full LaTeX report (title, abstract, introduction, methodology, results, discussion, conclusion, references) integrating figures and citing the literature retrieved; 3.  Ensure references are provided in bibitem format and that all paths and figure names match the generated files.  After assembling and validating the LaTeX code I will output the complete paper.  No further code is needed, only documentation and write-up.
